aPLFRx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Use hydro buffers only within selected MUs.

PREVIOUS MODEL NOTES: Because none of the natural systems map units specifically address the ecoregions and habitats within the geographic range of this species (i.e. prairies of southwestern IN), it would be easiest to simply select all habitats within the hydro buffers.

Removed forest/open edge criteria and hand modeling check. MJR 6dec06

references: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
Stebbins, R. C. 1985. A Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xiv + 336 pp.
Brown, L.E. 1992. Rana blairi. Pp. 536.1–536.6. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles. Society for the Study of Amphibians and Reptiles, St. Louis, Missouri.
Degenhardt, W.G., C.W. Painter and A.H. Price. 1996. Amphibians and Reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico.
Johnson, T.R. 1997. The Amphibians and Reptiles of Missouri. Missouri Department of Conservation, Jefferson City, Missouri.
habitat_description:
Found across southeast and central South Dakota and west Iowa into south and east New Mexico, central Texas, southeast Colorado, central Indiana and Oklahoma. In New Mexico, its distribution occurs along the Rio Hondo, Rio Bonito, and the upper reaches of Rio Peñasco (2130m) in the vicinity of Sierra Blanca in Lincoln County. Also found along the Pecos River near Carlsbad in Eddy County and along the Rio Grande to include Ash Canyon by Truth or Consequences in Sierra County. Other reports include disjunct populations on the west side of the Chiricahua Mountains in Turkey Creek specifically and the neighboring Sulphur Springs Valley in Cochise County, Arizona. Hybridization with the northern leopard frog is reported along the Cimarron River in the vicinity of Springer, along Mora River downstream of Wolf Creek, and along the Rio Grande specifically north of Elephant Butte Reservoir. Hybridization with the Rio Grande leopard frog is reported to occur throughout the overlapping portion their range (Conant and Collins 1998; Stebbins 2003). In Colorado, plains leopard frogs only occur below 1828 meters (Hammerson 1999). Furthermore, in Arizona, this species is found in cattle tanks, ditches, ponds, and streams found in Semidesert Grassland and Madrean Evergreen Woodland. Persist only in two of its historical localities in the state (Brennan and Holycross 2009; Brown et al. 1993; Degenhardt et al. 1996). Also in Arizona, this species occurs on the western side of the Chiricahua Mountains and the proximate Sulfer Springs Valley at an elevational range of 110 to 2590 meters (Stebbins 1985). In Missouri, this species is found everywhere but in the Ozark Plateau and in the extreme southeast region of the state (Brown 1992).
Primarily found in desert and prairie grasslands of central south Great Plains. Also known to utilize oak and oak-pine woodlands as well as farmland. This species can be found in prairie streams, ponds, and playas characterized as muddy and shallow (Stebbins 2003). Breeding takes place in temporary pools (Stebbins 2003), margins of ponds, marshes, and streams (Behler and King 1979). Also in ditches, streams, temporary pools, river sloughs, wetlands, marshes, and canyon pools (Stebbins 1985).
